questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

Some of the water losses cannot be precisely regulated. For example, there is a continuous loss of water by evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin, which together account for about 700 ml/day of water loss under normal conditions. This is termed insensible water loss because we are not consciously aware of it, even though it occurs continually in all living humans. It is about 700 mL/day or 50 mL/hour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal insensible water loss is approximately 50 mL/hour, resulting from evaporation through the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

The genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve that arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves. It descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from the lateral border of the muscle. It then divides into two branches: The genital branch, which supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the mons pubis, labia majora or scrotum, and cremaster muscle in males.

 

The femoral branch, which passes laterally over the iliacus muscle and descends along the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle. It supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the femoral triangle and the upper anterior thigh.

 

In addition to its sensory functions, the genitofemoral nerve also provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males, which raises the testes towards the body in response to cold or other stimuli. Dysfunction of the genitofemoral nerve can lead to sensory loss or motor weakness in the areas it innervates.

 

 

During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia is typically administered in the area inferior to the inguinal ligament and close to the femoral pulse. Among the given options, the genitofemoral nerve is the one most likely to be anesthetized during this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the ventral rami of the L2-L4 spinal nerves. It descends through the iliopsoas muscle and enters the femoral triangle, lateral to the femoral vessels. The femoral nerve primarily supplies muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. While it is in close proximity to the femoral vein, it is not the primary nerve targeted during femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve originates from the L2-L3 levels of the lumbar plexus. It travels inferiorly and exits the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, close to the anterior superior iliac spine, to supply the skin on the lateral aspect of the thigh. While it is near the inguinal ligament, its location is more lateral compared to the site of femoral vein catheterization, making it less likely to be affected.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve arises from the L1 level of the lumbar plexus. It travels through the inguinal canal and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, mons pubis, and scrotum or labium majus. The course and distribution of this nerve make it less relevant for femoral vein catheterization, which occurs more medially and inferiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1-L2 levels of the lumbar plexus. It descends on the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle and then splits into two branches: the genital and femoral branches. The femoral branch pierces the fascia lata to provide sensory innervation to a small area of skin over the femoral triangle. Given its anatomical location and course, this nerve is likely to be anesthetized during femoral vein catheterization.

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Identify the areas marked F, C in the following diagram: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

 

  • Area F: Positioned in the lower left part of the diagram, which corresponds to higher PCO2 and a pH less than 7.35. This area represents Acute Respiratory Acidosis due to an increase in CO2, causing a drop in blood pH.
  • Area C: Positioned in the upper right part of the diagram, which corresponds to lower PCO2 and a pH greater than 7.45. This area represents Acute Respiratory Alkalosis caused by a decrease in CO2, increasing blood pH.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the relationship between pH, bicarbonate (HCO3-), and CO2 is crucial for interpreting arterial blood gases. Area F indicates acute respiratory acidosis due to increased CO2, and area C indicates acute respiratory alkalosis due to decreased CO2.

choices.text: Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance
Stria albicans – Cushing syndrome
Xeroderma pigmentosum – Freckles
Café au lait spots – McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: An overweight 13-year-old girl has the following blackish discoloration on her neck, as shown in the image below. What is this condition and its association? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acanthosis nigricans – Insulin resistance

 

Option A.

 

Acanthosis Nigricans:

 

  • This condition is characterized by velvety, hyperpigmented plaques typically found in the intertriginous areas such as the neck, axilla, and groin.
  • The lesion’s appearance in the image is consistent with Acanthosis Nigricans.
  • It is commonly associated with insulin resistance and can be a marker for type 2 diabetes mellitus, especially in the context of overweight or obesity, as seen in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Striae Albicans:

 

  • This refers to the white or silver stretch marks that occur when the skin has been stretched rapidly as in the case of rapid weight gain or with conditions like Cushing syndrome.

 

 

  • However, the image does not show stretch marks but rather a hyperpigmented, thickened area of skin.

 

Option C. Xeroderma Pigmentosum:

 

  • This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extreme sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) rays from sunlight, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer.

 

 

  • The lesions associated with this condition are more freckle-like and do not resemble the thick, velvety texture seen in the image.

 

Option D. Café au lait spots:

 

  • These are light brown to dark brown spots commonly associated with neurofibromatosis or McCune-Albright syndrome.

 

 

  • Unlike Acanthosis Nigricans, café au lait spots are smooth in texture and uniform in pigmentation, not velvety or thickened.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize Acanthosis Nigricans by its velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the neck and its association with insulin resistance in the context of obesity.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 87.2

questions.text: Which metal causes the endemic peripheral vascular disease known as Blackfoot disease?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation
  • Below picture shows Blackfoot disease:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony does not cause Blackfoot disease. It can cause other toxic effects but is not specifically linked to peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option C. Barium: Barium toxicity is primarily associated with gastrointestinal and muscular symptoms rather than peripheral vascular disease.

 

Option D. Cadmium: While cadmium can cause peripheral vascular disease, it does not specifically lead to Blackfoot disease, which is uniquely associated with arsenic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blackfoot disease, characterized by darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs, is specifically caused by chronic arsenic poisoning. Other heavy metals such as cadmium, lead, and mercury can cause peripheral vascular disease, but Blackfoot disease is unique to arsenic exposure.

choices.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning

questions.text: Identify the left curve, given the fact that the right curve is of adult hemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation

 

  • The left curve is for myoglobin as it is a rectangular hyperbola curve which is characteristic of Michaelis Menton kinetics.
  • Fetal hemoglobin, CO poisoning and acidosis will shift the sigmoidal shape of hemoglobin saturation curve as shown in the image below:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal hemoglobin: Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin, which shifts the curve to the left. However, the curve still maintains a sigmoidal shape.

 

Option C. Carbon monoxide poisoning: Carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin with a much higher affinity than oxygen, shifting the hemoglobin dissociation curve to the left and making it more difficult for oxygen to be released to tissues. This also retains the sigmoidal shape.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Acidosis generally causes a rightward shift of the hemoglobin oxygen dissociation curve, reducing hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This is the opposite of what is observed with myoglobin.

The left shift observed in the myoglobin curve reflects its high affinity for oxygen, distinguishing it from the sigmoidal curves seen in hemoglobin variations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myoglobin has a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve due to its single polypeptide chain and high oxygen affinity, contrasting with the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin due to its cooperative binding.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient on medication presents with the lab values as shown below. (INICET MAY 2022)

 

Which of the following drugs should be stopped?
 

K+ :6.5 meg/L

Na+ :137 meg/L

Urea: 42 mg/dL

Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Losartan
 

Let's analyze the lab values and determine which medication, if any, should be stopped:

 

  1. Elevated Potassium (K+): A potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L is higher than the normal range (usually around 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L). High potassium levels, known as hyperkalemia, can be a concern, especially for patients taking certain medications that can affect potassium levels.
  2. Normal Sodium (Na+): A sodium level of 137 mEq/L falls within the normal range. There is no immediate concern regarding sodium levels.
  3. Elevated Urea and Creatinine: Urea and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating impaired kidney function. This is a significant concern, as it may suggest that the kidneys are not effectively filtering waste products from the blood.

 

Considering the elevated potassium level and impaired kidney function (elevated urea and creatinine), it is important to stop any drug that causes hyperkalemia. Among the given drugs, losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB), which can lead to hyperkalemia by blocking the action of the RAAS pathway. Since this patient has developed Hyperkalemia, Losartan should be stopped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not typically affect potassium levels and does not need to be stopped in this scenario.

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic used for hypertension. It usually causes hypokalemia (low potassium levels), not hyperkalemia. Therefore, it does not need to be stopped in this case.

 

Option D. Furosemide: A loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension. Furosemide usually causes hypokalemia and can actually be used to help lower elevated potassium levels. Hence, it should not be stopped and might even be beneficial in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hypertensive patient with hyperkalemia and impaired kidney function, Losartan should be stopped due to its potential to exacerbate hyperkalemia. Amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and furosemide do not typically increase potassium levels and do not need to be stopped. In fact, furosemide may help in lowering the elevated potassium levels.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: What is the most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

COVID-19 can cause various ocular manifestations, with follicular conjunctivitis being the most common. This is due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors in the cornea and conjunctiva, making them susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

FOLLICULAR CONJUNCTIVITIS:

 

 

  • The follicles appear as gray-white, round to oval elevations which measuring between 0.5 to 1.5 mm in diameter
  • Smaller follicles may produce a slightly irregular and velvety appearance
  • Follicles can be seen in the inferior and superior tarsal conjunctiva, and less often, on bulbar or limbal conjunctiva 
    • Acute follicular conjunctivitis is usually associated with viral (epidemic keratoconjunctivitis, Herpes zoster keratoconjunctivitis, infectious mononucleosis, Epstein-Barr virus infection) or chlamydial infections (Inclusion conjunctivitis), while chronic disease may be caused by chronic chlamydial infection (trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum) or as a toxic or reactive inflammatory response to topical medications and molluscum contagiosum infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: There are no consistent reports linking uveitis directly as a common manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Mucormycosis: Although mucormycosis (commonly known as black fungus) has been seen in COVID-19 patients, it is generally associated with severely immunocompromised states and not directly linked as a typical ocular manifestation of COVID-19 itself.

 

Option D. Papillary Conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis, characterized by cobblestone-like nodules, is more commonly associated with allergic reactions or chronic irritation from contact lenses rather than infectious etiologies like COVID-19.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Conversion disorder

 

La Belle indifference can be seen in Conversion disorder.

 

CONVERSION DISORDER

 

ICD-11 uses the term ‘dissociative neurological symptom disorder’

 

  • Patients present with symptoms suggestive of motor, sensory or cognitive deficits; however, no neurological cause can be found.
  • Also, the symptoms do not conform to the anatomical and physiological principles

 

Patients may have ‘la belle indifference’, which is a lack of concern for the symptoms. E.g., A patient with sudden onset loss of vision in an eye may appear unconcerned with her symptom.

choices.text: Vitamin C

questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ritonavir


 

  • Both Ritonavir and Saquinavir are Protease inhibitors that can be used in the treatment of HIV.
  • They are metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme system. But at the same time, Ritonavir is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4. Therefore, if small doses of Ritonavir are added along with Saquinavir, it will inhibit the metabolism of Saquinavir or in other words will boost the bioavailability and concentration of Saquinavir.

questions.text: A patient with alkaline urine has the presence of the following type of urinary crystals. What is the likely composition of these crystals?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

The presence of urinary crystals can help diagnose the type of stones a patient may be forming. The type of crystal seen in the urine is highly dependent on the urine pH:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite): These crystals are typically found in alkaline urine and have a characteristic "coffin lid" appearance. They are associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria and are also known as staghorn calculi due to their large, branching structure in the kidneys.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Calcium oxalate: These crystals are typically found in acidic to neutral urine and have an envelope or dumbbell shape. They are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Option B. Uric acid: These crystals are found in acidic urine and often have a rosette or irregular shape.

 

Option C. Cystine: These crystals appear in acidic urine and have a hexagonal shape, associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals, which appear as "coffin lid" shapes, are typically found in alkaline urine and are associated with struvite stones.

 

Urinary Crystals and pH Association:

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

 

The supracardinal vein gives rise to the structure indicated in the provided figure, which is the azygos vein.

 

The vein network known as the azygos system serves as a conduit between the superior and inferior venae caves. It resides in the posterior mediastinum and higher portion of the posterior abdominal wall. Moreover, it links the vertebral venous, caval, and portal systems. It drains the top part of the lumbar spine and the thoracic wall.

 

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins embryologically. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

 

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empties into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • On the left, the 4th to 7th intercostal veins enters into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein, then known as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.
  • Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,
  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

 

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

 

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common cardinal vein: common cardinal veins drain the embryonic body into the sinus venosus. These are early, primitive venous systems that mainly regress but give rise to parts of the systemic venous system. Specifically, the common cardinal vein will give rise to the sinus venarum of the right atrium and the oblique vein of the left atrium.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal vein: The anterior cardinal veins develop later and drain the cranial part of the embryo. With further development, the bilateral anterior cardinal veins will form the internal jugular vein and the brachiocephalic vein after some remodeling and anastomosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Option D. Subcardinal vein: The subcardinal veins primarily play a role in the development of the renal and gonadal venous systems. They give rise to the renal segment of the inferior vena cava and the gonadal veins. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, lesions on the shaft of penis are as shown below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen nitidus

 

The image shows an aggregate of skin colored papules over the shaft of penis of a child which is suggestive of lichen nitidus.

 

  • Lichen nitidus most frequently affects children or young adults.
  • The dorsum of the forearms or penis is where Lichen Nitidus most commonly manifests as tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules. In early lesions, Lichen Nitidus and Lichen planus share a similar histological profile. Mucous membrane involvement is quite rare in lichen nitidus. True Koebner’s phenomenon is evident.
  • Lesions are self-limiting & no treatment is required.

 

 

Above Image depicts lichen nitidus over elbow with True Koebner’s phenomenon seen.

 

  • As both LP and Lichen Nitidus share a similar histological profile in early lesions, they are both regarded as variants of LP.
  • Claw clutching Ball appearance: The Ball is comprised of well circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & occasional Langhan’s giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall claw clutching ball appearance.
  • Lesions are typically asymptomatic and infrequently need medical attention.
  • The histology of Lichen Nitidus is shown in the image below, where a well-defined granuloma is surrounded by rete pegs and appears to be claw clutching a ball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus: This condition often presents as purplish, flat-topped bumps as shown in the image below, these lesions can be itchy. The lesions can also affect mucosal surfaces forming white lacy / reticulate pattern. The described presentation and the image provided do not align with this diagnosis.

 

 

Option C. Scrofuloderma: It is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis which results from the direct invasion of the tubercle bacillus into the skin from underlying tuberculous foci.

 

  • It typically presents as cold abscesses, ulcers, or nodules as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Scabies: This parasitic infection presents with intense itching.

 

  • The burrows of the mite may be seen on the skin, typically in the interdigital spaces.
  • The lesions in the image do not match the typical appearance of scabies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen nitidus is a probable diagnosis in a child with asymptomatic lesions on the forearm and genitalia, especially when the lesions appear as tiny, flesh-colored bumps.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 page no 37.3, 37.10, 37.11, 37.39

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition Page no 554

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. HIV  
  2. SLE  
  3. CLL  
  4. Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPG) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.

 

MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.

 

The causes of MPGN are as follows:

 

  • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  • Secondary MPGN
  • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoarterial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
  • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

 

MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis.

 

There are 2 types of MPGN:

 

 

  • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN can be seen in various conditions, including HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B, making it important to consider these diseases in the differential diagnosis of MPGN

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 1777

questions.text: For HbA1c sample, the vacutainer used contains which of the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EDTA

 

Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) is measured to assess long-term glycemic control in diabetic patients. The preferred sample for HbA1c estimation is whole blood, and the anticoagulant used for this is EDTA.

 

  • EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is used because:
    • It prevents coagulation by chelating calcium.
    • It preserves RBC integrity, ensuring accurate measurement of glycosylated hemoglobin.
    • Lavender-top (Purple) vacutainers contain EDTA and are commonly used for HbA1c testing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: 

 

  • Warfarin is an anticoagulant used therapeutically, not for blood collection.

 

Option B. Sodium Fluoride:

 

  • Used in gray-top vacutainers, primarily for glucose estimation, as it inhibits glycolysis.
  • Does not preserve RBCs well, so not used for HbA1c.

 

Option D. Heparin:

 

  • Used in green-top vacutainers, primarily for plasma-based tests (e.g., electrolytes, arterial blood gases).
  • Not used for HbA1c, as it does not preserve whole blood effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HbA1c estimation, EDTA (lavender-top vacutainer) is used because it prevents coagulation while preserving RBC integrity for accurate glycosylated hemoglobin measurement.

 

Vacutainer Vials and Their Uses

 

 

Sequence of blood Drawn - Chalo Bhai, Red yellow Green Light → Go

 

Culture Bottle – Blue – Red – Yellow – Green – Lavender – Grey

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells)

questions.text: A child is brought to OPD with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Patient reported that it initially started as macule and later developed to become nodules. On examination, you noticed that some nodules have central umbilication. Microscopy finding is shown below. Identify the finding: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells): These are typically seen in herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and are not related to molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option B. Donovan bodies: These are characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Koilocytes: These are squamous epithelial cells that have undergone specific changes due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, are pathognomonic for molluscum contagiosum, a poxvirus infection.

questions.text: A young child presented with nocturnal chest pain and a history of syncope has the ECG shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

  

The ECG provided shows the characteristic pattern of Brugada syndrome, which includes:

 

  1. Pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern in leads V1 and V2.
  2. ST-segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1-V2).
  3. Coving of the ST segment.
  4. T-wave inversion following the ST-segment elevation.

 

Brugada syndrome is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, often occurring at rest or during sleep. It is more prevalent in young males and can present with symptoms such as nocturnal chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac arrest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: Typically presents with ST-segment elevation in contiguous leads but does not usually show the pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and possible left atrial enlargement, often presenting with deep Q waves and signs of left ventricular hypertrophy on ECG, not the specific pattern seen here.

 

Option D. DCM (Dilated Cardiomyopathy): Shows global left ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, which can lead to low voltage QRS complexes, left bundle branch block, or non-specific ST-T changes but not the specific Brugada pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brugada syndrome should be suspected in patients, especially young males, with a history of syncope or nocturnal chest pain presenting with the characteristic ECG pattern of pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2.

choices.text: Mullerian agenesis
Gonadal dysgenesis
Turner syndrome
Testicular feminization syndrome

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mullerian agenesis

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.
  • Absent uterus and vagina in a person with female genotype and phenotype are features of Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • As ovaries are present, normal secondary sexual characters will develop

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Gonadal dysgenesis: Gonadal dysgenesis patients present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters poorly developed breasts

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters and short stature will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. The ovaries are streak ovaries

 

Option D. Testicular feminization syndrome: Testicular feminization syndrome also known as androgen insensitivity syndrome has a karyotype of 46XY. Secondary sexual characters like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

 

Educational Objective:


Mullerian agenesis is characterized by the absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina, with normal ovarian function leading to normal breast and pubic hair development.

 

Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Infertility
  2. Dysmenorrhea
  3. Vaginal discharge
  4. Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside the uterus. This condition is associated with specific symptoms:

 

1. Infertility: Women with endometriosis often experience difficulty conceiving. The presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus can interfere with the reproductive organs, leading to infertility.

 

2. Dysmenorrhea: Painful menstruation is a hallmark of endometriosis. This condition can cause severe menstrual cramps due to the endometrial tissue responding to hormonal changes as it would in a normal menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3, 4: Vaginal discharge and vaginal bleeding are not characteristic symptoms of endometriosis. Vaginal discharge may be seen in various other conditions but is not specific to endometriosis. Similarly, while endometriosis can cause abnormal bleeding, it typically presents with pain rather than increased vaginal bleeding.

 

Option B. 2, 3: While dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) is a symptom of endometriosis, vaginal discharge is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Dysmenorrhea is indeed a symptom of endometriosis, but increased vaginal bleeding is not a primary symptom of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis commonly presents with symptoms including dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation) and infertility.


Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent form of contraception and is not classified as a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC). It involves the surgical closure or blocking of the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy permanently.

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC) methods are effective for extended periods and can be reversed if desired. They include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T: Correct. Copper T is an intrauterine device (IUD) that can provide contraception for several years.

 

Option B. Implanon: Correct. Implanon is a type of contraceptive implant that provides effective contraception for several years.

 

Option D. SC DMPA: This is a LARC. It is a sub cutaneous preparation of depot medroxy progesterone acetate and is administered once in 3 months

 

Educational Objective:


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent method of contraception and is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC).

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario presented here is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is caused by a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, denoted as 3.

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together using the mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

 

Other features that may be associated with DiGeorge syndrome include developmental delays, learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders. Treatment usually involves managing the individual symptoms and providing support to address any developmental or behavioral challenges

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1 - first pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, primarily associated with the development of structures like the middle ear and Eustachian tube.

 

Option B (2 - second pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, related to formations such as the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D (4 - fourth pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, although related to the development of superior parathyroid glands, it is not primarily responsible for the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands like the third pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

 

 

The third pharyngeal pouch's proper development is crucial for the normal formation of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Disruption in this development can lead to significant clinical symptoms like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, emphasizing the need for genetic testing and comprehensive clinical management in affected individuals.

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by placenta? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) hCG

 

Explanation:

 

  • Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is the hormone secreted by the placenta. It is a glycoprotein produced by the syncytiotrophoblast cells of the placenta.
  • hCG can be detected in the maternal serum or urine as early as 8-9 days post-fertilization using radioimmunoassay. In early pregnancy, hCG concentrations in plasma double every 1.4-2 days.
  • The primary role of hCG is to maintain the corpus luteum during the beginning of pregnancy, ensuring the continued production of progesterone, which is critical for maintaining the uterine lining and supporting pregnancy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. LH: Luteinizing Hormone is produced by the anterior pituitary gland, not by the placenta. It plays a key role in regulating the menstrual cycle and ovulation.

 

Option C. FSH: Follicle-Stimulating Hormone is also produced by the anterior pituitary gland. It is involved in the development of ovarian follicles and the regulation of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option D. GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone is produced by the hypothalamus, it stimulates the anterior pituitary gland to release FSH and LH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone secreted by the placenta, crucial for maintaining early pregnancy by supporting the corpus luteum and progesterone production.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg266, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 66

questions.text: All are used in recombinant DNA technology (genetic engineering) except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Isomerases

 

Isomerases are not used in recombinant DNA technology. Isomerases are enzymes that catalyze structural rearrangements within a molecule, converting one isomer to another. They don't have applications in genetic engineering techniques where cutting, joining, or modifying DNA sequences is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatases: These are used in recombinant DNA technology. Alkaline phosphatase removes terminal phosphate groups from DNA, which is useful in preventing unwanted ligation reactions in DNA cloning.

 

Option B. CRISPR Cas9:
 

CRISPR/CAS 9 System:

  • Causes double strand break
  • CROSPR- Clustered Regularly Interspersed Short Palindromic Repeats
  • Cas-9: CRISPR associated endonuclease
    • This endonuclease is guided by CRISPR for cutting site
  • It is an immune system in bacteria against bacteriophages
    • Memory of bacteriophage infection and immunity is transferred to future generation also. So protect may future generations from viruses

Uses

  • Can be adopted to be used in eukaryotes for purposes like
    • Gene deletion
    • Exogenous gene insertion
    • Multigene editing possible
    • Altering gene transcription and regulation 

 

Option D. Terminal transferase: This enzyme is used in recombinant DNA technology to add nucleotides to the 3' OH end of DNA, which is useful in various molecular biology applications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isomerases, which catalyze structural rearrangements within molecules, are not used in recombinant DNA technology or genetic engineering, while phosphatases, CRISPR Cas9, and terminal transferase are utilized in these techniques.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency.(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Potency of Anesthetic Agents:

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.

 

MAC Values:

  • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • Halothane: 0.75
  • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • Nitrous oxide: 104

 

Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):

  • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.

 

Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.

 

Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was started on amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). The patient was later found unconscious at home and brought to the emergency department. On examination, the patient shows signs of arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation. Which of the following does NOT suggest TCA poisoning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothermia

 

Hypothermia is NOT typically associated with TCA poisoning. In fact, hyperthermia may occur due to anticholinergic effects leading to decreased sweating and heat dissipation.

 

Other Options:

 

Tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning can lead to a variety of clinical manifestations, primarily due to their anticholinergic, sodium channel-blocking, and alpha-adrenergic blocking effects. The key features in this case would be:

 

Option A. Arrhythmias:

 

  • TCAs block sodium channels, leading to cardiac conduction delays, which can manifest as arrhythmias. They can also cause QT prolongation, predisposing to torsades de pointes.
  • Therefore, arrhythmias are a common and significant feature of TCA poisoning.

 

Option B. Confusion:

 

  • The anticholinergic effects of TCAs can lead to mental status changes, including confusion, agitation, and even delirium.
  • Confusion is a typical presentation in TCA overdose.

 

Option D. Pupillary Dilation:

 

  • Anticholinergic effects also include pupillary dilation (mydriasis) due to paralysis of the iris sphincter muscle.
  • Pupillary dilation is often observed in TCA toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is not a typical feature of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning, whereas arrhythmias, confusion, and pupillary dilation are common clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: In 18th century British East India company used to transport which substance of abuse to China: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opium

 

Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the British East India Company exported vast quantities of opium to China, leading to widespread addiction and the Opium Wars, which had significant geopolitical consequences.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marijuana: A psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Option D. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China.

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus

questions.text: Donor blood should be screened for the following infections except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dengue virus

 

Dengue virus is not typically included in the mandatory screening process for blood donations. While dengue is a significant public health issue, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions, its transmission through blood transfusion is rare and not considered a primary risk compared to the other pathogens listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis C virus: This virus is a common cause of liver disease and is a bloodborne pathogen. Blood donations are routinely screened for HCV to prevent transmission through transfusion.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: HIV is a critical pathogen to screen for in donated blood because it can be transmitted through blood transfusion and is responsible for causing AIDS.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B virus: Like HCV, HBV is a major bloodborne pathogen that can lead to serious liver disease. Blood is routinely screened for HBV to ensure it is safe for transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Donor blood require screening for infectious disease pathogen:

 

  • Hepatitis C virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  • Hepatitis B virus
  • Malaria 
  • Syphilis.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

choices.text: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
Acute Myeloid Leukemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is being evaluated for leukemia. On investigation, WBC count was 4,50,000 /µL with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia  

 

A WBC count of 4,50,000/µL with eosinophilia and basophilia indicates a probable diagnosis of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia presents with pancytopenia

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia shows smudge cells and small round lymphocytes in peripheral smear.

 

Option D. Acute Myeloid Leukemia: Acute Myeloid Leukemia shows myeloblasts with Auer rods. Clinically, patients have pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia is characterized by extreme leukocytosis with eosinophilia and basophilia, and it is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome and the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Phase zero in the adjoining image is due to which of the following? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium influx

 

In the nodal tissue, Phase 0 is due to the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, which causes the rapid depolarization of the pacemaker potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sodium influx: While a slow influx of sodium occurs during the pacemaker potential's initial phase, it is not responsible for the rapid depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Potassium ions generally move out of the cell during repolarization and do not contribute to the depolarization seen in Phase 0 of nodal tissue.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Potassium efflux occurs mainly during repolarization, which corresponds to phases 3 and 4 in the nodal tissue, not during the depolarization of Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nodal tissue, such as the SA node, Phase 0 of the action potential is caused by the rapid influx of calcium ions through voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to the rapid depolarization that initiates the action potential.

questions.text: A man in his 50s comes to the emergency room with severe abdominal pain. During the examination, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is measured at 90/50mmg. Guarding is observed during a per abdomen examination. An erect abdominal X-ray is provided. What is the best management in this case based on these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exploratory laparotomy

 

Given clinical scenario of tachycardia, hypotension with abdominal guarding and X ray showing pneumoperitoneum is suggestive of hollow viscous perforation. The best management would be laparotomy and repair. The next step would be IV fluids.

 

Given the patient's severe abdominal pain, guarding during the physical examination, tachycardia, and hypotension, along with X ray findings suggest a perforation. An exploratory laparotomy would allow for direct visualization and treatment of the underlying cause. In emergent situations like this, a surgical exploration might be the most appropriate next step. Hence, OPTION C is the most appropriate choice among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. USG abdomen: Ultrasonography (USG) of the abdomen is a non-invasive imaging technique used to visualize abdominal organs. It may be used for a preliminary assessment of abdominal pain, but in the case of a patient with severe pain, hemodynamic instability (as indicated by tachycardia and hypotension), and guarding, accompanied by X ray showing free air, a USG would not add to the management.

 

Option B. IV fluids: Administering IV fluids can help stabilize the patient's blood pressure and is an essential immediate measure. However, fluids alone might not address the underlying cause of perforation.

 

Option D. Elective surgery: Elective surgery is a planned procedure that is done when a condition is not immediately life-threatening. Given the severity of the patient's symptoms and the potential for an acute abdominal catastrophe, waiting for an elective procedure is not appropriate in this situation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas within the peritoneal cavity, the space within the abdomen that contains the intestines, liver, and other abdominal organs.

 

Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:

 

Patients with a significant amount of free air in the peritoneal cavity due to organ perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, signs of peritonitis (like guarding and rebound tenderness), and systemic symptoms like fever or shock. An erect abdominal X-ray is a commonly used diagnostic modality to detect pneumoperitoneum. On the X-ray, free air under the diaphragm, or "free subdiaphragmatic air", is a classic finding.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: The spinal trigeminal nucleus forms the second-order neuron of which of the following sensations? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pain

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus is located in the medulla and functions as a relay center, particularly for pain and temperature sensations from the face. It processes these sensations and transmits the information to higher brain centers for interpretation. The second-order neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus specifically relay pain and temperature information, making it a critical component in the sensory pathway for these modalities.

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus does not act as a relay center for other sensations like touch, two-point discrimination, or conscious proprioception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Touch: The sensation of touch is primarily processed through other pathways, such as the dorsal columns and the main sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, rather than the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option C. Two-point discrimination: This sensation is typically processed by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Option D. Conscious proprioception: Conscious proprioception is also processed via the dorsal columns, particularly through the cuneate and gracile nuclei, and not the spinal trigeminal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal trigeminal nucleus in the medulla serves as the second-order neuron relay center specifically for pain and temperature sensations from the face.

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

 

The image shown is of Whipple’s procedure, which can be done for distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

  • Whipple's procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, is a complex surgical procedure that involves removing the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the common bile duct, the gallbladder, and sometimes a portion of the stomach.
  • This procedure is typically performed to treat cancer of the pancreas, duodenum, or the ampulla of Vater

 

Distal cholangiocarcinoma is cancer that occurs in the bile ducts, typically in the lower part of the bile duct near the pancreas. The procedure referred to in the question is often associated with the surgical management of distal cholangiocarcinoma. It involves a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is a complex surgical procedure to remove the affected part of the bile duct, pancreas, and small intestine, and then reconstruct the digestive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Advanced gastric carcinoma: The management of advanced gastric carcinoma typically involves various approaches, including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. Surgical procedures such as gastrectomy or lymphadenectomy may be performed depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

 

Option B. Gallbladder carcinoma: Gallbladder carcinoma may be treated with surgical resection, often involving cholecystectomy (removal of the gallbladder) and potentially more extensive procedures if the cancer has spread. However, the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to gallbladder carcinoma.

 

Option D. Chronic calcific pancreatitis: Chronic calcific pancreatitis may require surgical intervention in certain cases, but the procedure mentioned in the question is not specific to this condition. Surgical options for chronic pancreatitis may include drainage procedures or resection of the affected pancreatic tissue.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The procedure mentioned in the question, which is often performed to manage distal cholangiocarcinoma, is a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy).
